{{Infobox NCAA Baseball Conference Tournament | | Year=2011 | Conference=Atlantic Coast Conference | ShortConference=ACC | Division= | Image=2011_ACC_Baseball_Championship_Logo.PNG | ImageSize=175px | Caption=2011 ACC baseball tournament logo | Teams=8 | Format=2 division [[Round-robin tournament|round robin]] and
[[Final (competition)|championship game]] | Ballpark= Durham Bulls Athletic Park | City= Durham, NC | 1stRoundBallpark= | 1stRoundCity= | QuarterBallpark= | QuarterCity= | SemiBallpark= | SemiCity= | FinalBallpark= | FinalCity= | Champions= [[Virginia Cavaliers baseball|Virginia Cavaliers]] | TitleCount=3rd | Coach=[[Brian O'Connor (baseball coach)|Brian O'Connor]] | CoachCount=2nd | MVP=Steven Proscia | MVPTeam=Virginia Cavaliers | Attendance= | Television=[[Regional sports network|RSN]] }} {{2011 Atlantic Coast Conference baseball standings}} The '''2011 Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament''' was held at the [[Durham Bulls Athletic Park]] in [[Durham, NC]] from May 25 through May 29. All of the games were shown live on [[Fox Sports South]] with select games being shown on [[Fox Sports Florida]], [[Comcast SportsNet Mid-Atlantic|Comcast Mid-Atlantic]], [[Sun Sports]], and [[New England Sports Network]]. Top seeded [[Virginia Cavaliers baseball|Virginia]] won the tournament and earned the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]]'s automatic bid to the [[2011 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament]]. It was Virginia's third ACC tournament win and second in three years. 2011 was the fifth year in which the conference used a [[round-robin tournament]] format, with the team with the best record in each group at the end of the three-game round robin advancing to a one-game championship. ==Seeding== {| | {| class="wikitable" |- | colspan="6" align="center"| '''Atlantic Division''' |- !
